intro: Euphrasia substituta, commonly known as the yellow-eyed grass, is a perennial herb native to North America. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, yellowish-orange flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and wetlands. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and often hairy, while its flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences. Euphrasia substituta is noted for its medicinal properties, historically used in traditional herbal remedies.
